item.title: 2024 Video Game Release Date Calendar
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Games in January 2024
  • Games in February 2024
  • Games in March 2024
  • Games in April 2024
  • Games in May 2024
  • Games in June 2024
  • Games in July 2024
  • Games in August 2024
  • Games in September 2024
  • Games in October 2024
  • Games in November 2024
  • Games in December 2024
  • Big 2024 TBA Games

2024 is another fantastic year for video games. Nintendo released a brand-new game starring Princess Peach; Dragon's Dogma finally got a sequel; the next part of the acclaimed Final Fantasy 7 remake came out; Star Wars is getting another open-world adventure, which just scratches the surface. We should expect many more 2024 video game release dates as more presentations happen, like the next State of Play, Nintendo Direct, and all the other online streams.

Interactive Calendar Here

Updated October 1...

The Alters has been pushed to early 2025.

So, for the gamers who would like to plan their gaming sessions ahead of time, here's a list of the major video games coming out in 2024 . We'll try to keep this article updated every week or so with any changes, such as delays, cancellations, and new announcements from the big publishers.

We'll list each month below and then have a 2024 TBA list at the bottom. The TBA section will have the 2024 video games that we don't have confirmed dates yet for but are still planned for release in the new year.

  • Games in January 2024

item.title: Naughty Dog Reveals Last of Us Part 1 Easter Egg That's Gone Unnoticed for Years
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Naughty Dog revealed an undiscovered Easter egg in The Last of Us Part 1 involving the main menu's lighting.
  • The Easter egg can be activated with specific button prompts that players were largely unaware of.
  • Despite celebrations for "The Last of Us Day," fans expressed disappointment at the lack of new game content.

Naughty Dog recently showed off an Easter egg in The Last of Us Part 1 that has managed to go unnoticed since release, allowing players to alter the main menu's lighting with a specific button prompt. The reveal came as a surprise to many fans online and serves as one of the seemingly new features added to The Last of Us Part 1, which served as a full-on remake of the original game.

The Last of Us is a fairly expansive game despite its linear storytelling and presentation, offering a variety of extra things for players to see and unlock, like unique character interactions, alternate costumes, and even visual filters. When The Last of Us Part 1 was released in 2022, it expanded the original version significantly and added several new elements, including some never-before-seen Easter eggs.

The official Naughty Dog Twitter account recently demonstrated one such Easter egg with a video showing off the ability to change the lighting on the game's home screen with a series of button presses. By pressing the D-pad and Triangle button on PS5, or the "E" key in the PC version of The Last of Us Part 1 in a specific sequence, the lighting coming through the window on the main menu will change color to a brighter white hue.

Undiscovered The Last of Us Part 1 Easter Egg Blows Up Online

Typically, the lighting changes automatically when players select the Left Behind DLC in The Last of Us Part 1 , but by pressing buttons in the sequence shown, the lighting can be changed manually instead. Fans were largely shocked by the reveal in the replies to the tweet, stating that in all their time playing, they had never discovered the feature, seemingly due to the very specific sequence required to achieve it.

The reveal came as part of the developer's routine celebration of "The Last of Us Day" on September 26, which commemorates the in-universe date in which the cordyceps fungal outbreak kicked off the apocalypse. Despite the occasion, however, many fans expressed frustration toward Naughty Dog for the lack of meaningful new content for the series , such as the now-defunct The Last of Us multiplayer game which the developer previously promised.

That being said, the company did give its other major series some attention with a remastered collection of the Uncharted series for the PlayStation 5 and is seemingly at work on a mysterious new IP, so it remains to be seen what will come from it in the future. Speculation surrounding a potential third entry in the Last of Us series has recently abounded along with the upcoming release of the second season of its critically acclaimed HBO television adaptation.

item.title: When Games Turn Into Movie Scenes #15
item.description: Some truly epic moments from Battlefield, Cyberpunk 2077, and more.

item.title: Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom Proves Classic Zelda Doesn't Have to Face the Reaper
item.description:
With the release of Zelda: Breath of the Wild back in 2017, Nintendo's iconic Legend of Zelda franchise took on a whole new look. The gameplay was vastly different from what came before, the freedom the studio gave players was unprecedented, and it is still often lauded as one of the best things the open-world genre has to offer. Of course, that success meant that Nintendo went full speed ahead on a sequel with Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom , which took the concept even further. While it seemed like this may be the franchise's future, Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom has revived what came before instead.

Now, Legend of Zelda fans are being treated to an old-school Zelda game rather than the massive new approach the studio adopted. Through Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom , they are being brought on another fantastic adventure that does not feel limited by its top-down nature. And because of its success, this type of Zelda game may not be left by the wayside after all.

The Classic Legend of Zelda Experience Has a Bright Future Ahead of It

Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom Feels Like a Blast from the Past

Although Zelda: Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom are fantastic games, they really do not share many similarities with previous games. Instead of being a top-down action adventure filled with dungeons to conquer and treasures to find, these games fully embraced what an open-world game could be. Much of that was left behind in favor of a massive open-world Hyrule, completely revamped gameplay with whole new mechanics and shorter puzzle-based shrines rather than the dungeons of the past. But, instead of further expanding upon that, Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom has taken a step back.

Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom feels like what old-school Zelda games have that modern games are sometimes missing. It brought the franchise back to its top-down roots, delivered that classic dungeon-crawler experience, and told a whole new story through the eyes of Princess Zelda. Additionally, the studio injected a few Breath of the Wild -like mechanics to help keep it feeling fresh and unique. And through all that, it has delivered an experience that fans may not soon forget.

The Future of Zelda Can Juggle Both Approaches

Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom 's success is great to see, as it shows that there is still a place for these classic titles alongside the massive new adventures Nintendo has been crafting. Of course, this would hardly be the first time that Legend of Zelda has explored different styles. In these last couple of years, players have also been treated to Hyrule Warriors: Age of Calamity , Skyward Sword HD , and the Link's Awakening remake. But, unlike those games, Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom is a fully-fledged new entry into the mainline series, which makes its approach feel even more special.

There is seemingly no reason titles like Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom should stop, but now, players could also be treated to that classic Zelda model as well. Not only would that help keep the franchise feeling fresh and diverse, but these top-down adventures by Grezzo could also serve as fantastic ways to bridge the gap between the larger open-world titles. Plus, with the unique mechanics it has tossed into the mix, these titles would likely never feel inferior to those adventures, even if they are smaller scale.

It remains to be seen just what the future of The Legend of Zelda entails. As of now, it seems like Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom will be the last mainline title for the Switch unless Nintendo has another surprise up its sleeve. But, whatever the future of the franchise looks like, there is seemingly space for both types of adventures within it.

item.title: 9 Forgotten PlayStation 2 Multiplayer Games That Need Remakes
item.description:
The PlayStation 2 had many multiplayer games that remain certified classics. Even now, veteran and newbie gamers find ways to play PS2 multiplayer, whether through official means or emulation. Chief among these are forgotten PS2 multiplayer games that need remakes .

Some series hit a dead end despite having a healthy fanbase. Others simply never got a sequel, even though they have plenty of lore left to explore, or fun multiplayer mechanics. A fortunate few got to go past the PS2, whether through direct sequels or re-releases, but eventually got waylaid. Whatever the case, these PS2 multiplayer games have enough going on that a remake will surely be a hit.

9 Crash of the Titans

An Underrated Crash Bandicoot Classic Packed With Co-Op Fun And Nostalgia

It’s not uncommon to hear stories about friends and siblings swapping out to complete levels in Crash Bandicoot . Crash of the Titans solved this perennial problem by having players team up to control the titular beasts. Co-op makes collecting Mojo easier, taking down Titans faster, and playing through tricky segments less frustrating.

Sadly for fans, a proper Crash game is not in the works, and a planned Crash Bandicoot 5 with a Spyro crossover was even canceled. Sadly, a lack of love for Crash means perhaps no future at the moment, especially one for his most underrated titles. Online co-op would also make the game more accessible, especially to long-distance friends and siblings.

8 Project Eden

Team-Based Shooter Peppered With Puzzles

Core, the team behind Tomb Raider 2 put their level design chops to work on Project Eden . The 2001 multiplayer PS2 game features drop-in/drop-out co-op that tasks up to four players with puzzle solving and squad-based shooting. Every member has a unique ability critical to passing these puzzles which, like Tomb Raider , take precedence over combat.

Project Eden ’s sci-fi, body horror-peppered story also belongs in the milieu of the new 20s. Although Lara Croft and the Temple of Osiris fit the puzzle-heavy, four-player slot, Project Eden ’s puzzles are simply more satisfying to solve. A Project Eden remake could be a great weekend game for friend groups who love arguing over puzzles and horror about artificial meat.

7 Warriors Orochi

ROTK & Japanese Historical Figures Meet In Musou Combat

Release Date

  • September 18, 2007 (Warriors Orochi)
  • October 16, 2018 (Warriors Orochi 4)

Developers

Koie, Omega Force

How Long To Beat It

149.5 hours (Cumulative)

Multiplayer Mode

  • Two player co-op
  • 3v3 competitive multiplayer

Systems

  • Microsoft Windows
  • Nintendo Switch
  • PlayStation 2
  • PlayStation 3
  • PlayStation 4
  • PlayStation Portable
  • Xbox 360
  • Xbox One

Warriors Orochi is a completely fictional cross-over between Chinese and Japanese historical and mythological characters that Musou fans still joke about fondly. It’s also a PlayStation 2 game that still looks good, even when compared to later series.

A remake could take advantage of stronger consoles to generate larger enemy populations without sacrificing performance. Warriors Orochi ’s Marvel vs. Capcom -like three-character structure could also give way to sick combos that are too performance-intensive on older generations. Koei-Tecmo could also borrow new multiplayer modes and mechanics from its newer games for a remake.

6 Gladius

Gladiatorial Action RPG With Surprising Depth

Anyone expecting a straight-action game set in the Roman Empire would be surprised once they dive into Gladius . The three-platform game by LucasArts is a TBTRPG with sim-raising aspects and magic. Players can tag team with up to two friends on the PS2 to complete the fairly long campaign, which is surprisingly engaging and fantastical.

With other LucasArts properties receiving updated re-releases, it’s disappointing that Gladius never got a second look. A tactics game where players can raise gladiators, send them to tournaments, and progress through the main story with friends has more appeal now, especially with games like Baldur’s Gate 3 out.

5 The Adventures of Cookie & Cream

Before Dark Souls, There Was Cookie & Cream

FromSoftware is an interesting company, as its games tend to skew towards difficult, dark, and interesting. The combo breaker is The Adventures of Cookie & Cream , the only original IP in their repertoire that’s sickeningly cute. It’s unmistakably a FromSoftware game though, evidenced by its tough puzzles, an unnerving-looking moon, and a bittersweet ending.

Although FromSoftware is known for their hair-tearingly difficult games now, a revisit to Cookie & Cream wouldn’t be amiss. In fact, it could be their once-in-a-blue-moon game, similar to Déraciné and Monster Hunter Diary of recent years.

4 Tenchu: Wrath of Heaven

Stealth Co-Op As Fun As Versus Mode

Release Date

March 3, 2003

Developers

K2

How Long To Beat It

  • 8 hours
  • 16 hours (100%)

Multiplayer Mode

Two player co-op

Systems

  • PlayStation 2
  • Xbox
  • Mobile
  • PlayStation Portable

A severely underserved franchise is the Tenchu series. Tenchu: Wrath of Heaven in particular had a thrilling versus mode. The roster of characters and their special abilities made for amazing battles and many broken controllers due to Chibot and Tesshu.

Moreover, while Tenchu: Wrath of Heaven tries to look serious, it’s ultimately campy and fun. It was a major stealth game at the time, one of the few fun ones on the PS2, and a title that allowed players to complete the campaign and compete with friends. As FromSoftware now pens rights to the game, a hard-as-nails remake with multiplayer options would be phenomenal.

3 Star Wars: Jedi Starfighter

3D Space Simulation Action With Force Powers

Release Date

March 11, 2002

Developers

Lucasfilm Games LLC

How Long To Beat It

  • 5.5 hours
  • 9.5 hours (100%)

Multiplayer Mode

Two player co-op

Systems

  • PlayStation 2
  • Xbox

What made Star Wars: Jedi Starfighter one-of-a-kind among its Star Wars space combat peers are its precise storytelling and evolving dogfighting controls. Its split-screen co-op invests players in the same focused story campaign, either as co-dogfighters or with one player in the ship’s turret.

Jedi Starfighter is a cult classic and a spiritual successor of sorts for the X-Wing and Rebel Assault series. And along with Rogue Squadron , it was a spaceflight sim that lasted through the early 2000s. Without a whiff of a sequel to Squadron , a Jedi Starfighter remake feels like the right move.

2 Mercenaries 2: World in Flames

Team Up With Friends As Mercenaries In Multi-Genre Multiplayer

Although stealth is part of the game, Mercenaries 2: World in Flames shines best when it allows the player to unleash hell. Every single building can be destroyed, despite the reputation hit to Mercenary ’s five factions. Mercenaries 2 improved on its predecessor, Playground of Destruction with a co-op mode that made the game stick around for a couple of years.

EA seems irreparably committed to live-service games now, but that doesn’t mean a Mercenaries remake can’t thrive. A Mercenaries remake in today’s EA model can have players form bands of mercenaries to take on campaigns and an online squad-based battle arena mode.

1 Time Crisis 3

Classic Light Gun Game Made Accessible On The PS2

Older players certainly haven’t forgotten Time Crisis 3 or the Time Crisis series in general. However, younger players probably don’t, and those who do likely think of it as an arcade game. Time Crisis 3 had a great PS2 port though, and one that has great alternative modes.

Co-op players get to enjoy a bigger arcade mode on the PS2. The exclusive alternate campaign is also more difficult, though it’s worth going through it to unlock OP features. A remake of the series on the PC and Nintendo Switch with these options would surely be a hit, especially with the ton of light gun options out on the market.
